title: All 12 universities in Gaza have been the target of Israeli attacks: 'It's a war against education'
summary: The higher education establishments in the Palestinian enclave have endured damage or complete destruction by Israeli forces. Three presidents and nearly a hundred deans and professors have so far been killed in the bombardments.

title: Sham marriages, false papers: Ukrainians' frantic quest to dodge the draft
summary: Instead of risking their lives by attempting to cross the border illegally, men are increasingly turning to other methods to avoid mobilization.

title: 2024 US presidential election: Nikki Haley drops out but doesn't endorse Donald Trump
summary: Super Tuesday was fatal to Haley, who only won two primaries and never presented herself as an 'anti-Trump' candidate. Biden, meanwhile, has reached out to her electors.

title: Images of the catastrophic situation in Haiti, under the threat of 'civil war' from a gang leader
summary: Amid reports of kidnappings, snipers on rooftops, and sexual violence, the UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting on the escalation of violence in Haiti, where a gang leader has threatened 'civil war' if Prime Minister Ariel Henry does not resign.

title: Champions League: Man City cruise into quarters, as Real Madrid 'suffer' in draw
summary: The two European powerhouses have now secured their spot in the quarter-finals alongside Bayern Munich and Paris Saint-Germain; the remaining qualifiers will be determined next week.

title: Digital Markets Act: How the way you use Google Maps and Messenger is changing
summary: New European Union regulation on digital markets is being enforced as of Wednesday, March 6, leading tech giants to modify certain functions of their services, with concrete effects on their European users' experience.

title: 'Rust' armorer convicted of involuntary manslaughter in fatal shooting by Alec Baldwin
summary: Prosecutors said on Wednesday, March 3, that Gutierrez-Reed unknowingly brought live ammunition onto the set of the movie (a ranch on the outskirts of Santa Fe), arguing that rounds lingered for at least 12 days until the fatal shooting.

title: Senegal: Confusion surrounds new date for presidential election
summary: President Macky Sall sparked a political crisis in early February by postponing the December 15 election, only to be overruled by the Constitutional Council. The government advanced on Wednesday the date of March 24 for the vote, moments before being contradicted, once again, by the top constitutional body.

title: Israel-Hamas war: Even Gaza's graveyards have suffered destruction
summary: Nearly half the burial sites in the Palestinian enclave have suffered damage by armored vehicles, air strikes and artillery fire from the Israeli army.

title: DR Congo: Over 100,000 more displaced in clashes
summary: The escalation underscores the deepening humanitarian crisis gripping the region, demanding urgent attention to protect civilian lives and address the underlying causes of the conflict.

title: Zelensky and Greece's prime minister visited Odesa as it was rocked by a blast
summary: The blast, a large explosion that the Russian military claimed as an attack on a hangar 'in which crewless cutters were being prepared for combat use,' was described as 'a very intense experience' by visiting Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis.

title: US Democrat challenger Dean Phillips ends primary run and endorses Biden
summary: Representative Dean Phillips, 55, a Democrat from Minnesota who had campaigned on a platform calling for a new generation of Democratic leadership, has ended his long-shot presidential bid after President Joe Biden's sweeping Super Tuesday victory.

title: Russia adds chess legend Kasparov to 'terrorists and extremists' list
summary: The former world chess champion has been a vocal opponent of Putin and has repeatedly spoken out against the military offensive in Ukraine.

title: At Roman Polanski's defamation trial, defense blames '#MeToo and its alternative accountability'
summary: The filmmaker was sued for defamation after calling actress Charlotte Lewis, who accused him of rape, a liar. His lawyers pleaded for acquittal in the name of the right to defend an 'accused person thrown to the wolves.'

title: Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell endorses Trump for president
summary: His announcement marked quite the turnaround as McConnell had previously blamed Donald Trump for 'disgraceful' acts in the January 6 2021 Capitol insurrection.

title: New York will deploy National Guard in subway after string of violent crimes
summary: The New York governor announced that 1,000 New York State Police, MTAPD and the New York National Guard will be used to support the NYPD in conducting bag checks.

title: Biden and Trump head for another face-off, after a surprise-less Super Tuesday
summary: The former president triumphed, confirming his stranglehold on the Republican Party and crushing his rival, Nikki Haley, who won only the state of Vermont.

title: Head of France's national cinema agency to be tried for sexual assault in June
summary: Dominique Boutonnat, 54, was accused of sexually assaulting his godson in 2020. Despite this accusation, Boutonnat had been reappointed as the head of France's powerful National Centre of Cinema (CNC) in 2022.

title: Thousands of animal experiments in France are conducted 'outside the regulatory framework'
summary: An administrative court has suspended 10 authorizations for research projects involving mice, hamsters and macaques.

title: Paris Olympics 2024: Police allegedly cracking down on sex workers before the Games
summary: A group of 17 non-government organizations have issued a report decrying a 'repression first' approach, employed by French police towards sex workers ahead of the 2024 Paris Olympic Games, which they claim harms 'the security and health of sex workers.'

title: Russia journalist jailed for seven years for criticizing Ukraine war
summary: Roman Ivanov was found guilty of spreading 'false information' on social media about Russia's armed forces and punished under Moscow's strict military censorship laws.
